qas.question: Reception statues are generally the same as what law?
Who sites pre-revolution cases when discussion evolution of judge-made law?
Which US State did not  enact reception statues?
What is the only state to not enact reception statutes?
What do reception statutes state is the law of the state?
Modern courts often cite which period in history cases when discussing changes in law?

answers.text: the common law of England (particularly judge-made law) is the law of the state
repugnant to domestic law or indigenous conditions

qas.question: Where did the bulk of the US's starting laws come from?
Which is the only stste without reception statutes?
What kind of case would a contemporary lawyer discuss when talking about an ancient judge-made common law principle?
What is the only US state to have a reception statute?
What form of English law has been considered repugnant to the US?

plausible_answers.text: the date of a colony's founding

qas.question: What specific date did Louisiana chose as a cutoff date?
What cases have contemporary courts thrown out?
Lowered duty of care is placed on what?

context: The actual substance of <a9_0>English law<a9_0/> was formally "received" into the United States in several ways. First, all U.S. states except <a2_0><a3_0><a10_0><b12_0>Louisiana<b12_0/><a10_0/><a3_0/><a2_0/> have enacted "reception statutes" which generally state that <a0_0><a7_0>the <a4_0>common law of England<a4_0/><a0_0/> (particularly <b13_0>judge-made<b13_0/> law) is the law of the state<a7_0/> to the extent that it is not <a8_0>repugnant to domestic law or indigenous conditions<a8_0/>. Some reception statutes impose <a5_0>a specific cutoff date<a5_0/> for reception, such as <b14_0>the date of a colony's founding<b14_0/>, while others are deliberately vague. Thus, <a1_0>contemporary U.S. courts<a1_0/> often cite <a6_0><a11_0><b15_0>pre-Revolution<b15_0/><a11_0/><a6_0/> cases when discussing the evolution of an ancient judge-made common law principle into its modern form, such as the heightened duty of care traditionally imposed upon <b16_0>common carriers<b16_0/>.
